content.webTitle: Let’s protect the foundations of UK creativity | Caroline Roux

fields.headline: Let’s protect the foundations of UK creativity
fields.bodyText: London fashion week draws to a close on Tuesday and the London design festival will really hit its stride over the next few days. By the end of the week, the two events combined will have drawn more than a million visitors to the capital, filling hotel rooms, restaurants and plenty of coffers besides. They are lured to London by its enduring reputation as one of the world’s truly creative capitals, and London makes sure that there’s plenty for them to see. The fashion week, which this season moved from the elegant surroundings of Somerset House to a rather more downbeat decommissioned car park in the centre of Soho, offered up shows by 78 designers. It is anticipated that £100m of orders will be placed. For its part, the London design festival (LDF) – with hubs from Queen’s Park in the northwest to Bankside over the river – helps ensure that the capital continues to be a design sponge, a city where people long to come to study, to shop, to open businesses. A place to find new talent and skilled employees. The mayor’s office certainly thinks so. It gives the LDF £250,000 a year, and supports fashion week and Film London. It has also just sanctioned the return of the London games festival (video game design is big business, and London’s position near the top of games production has recently slipped). But while it’s all very well – and culturally and economically useful – to celebrate design, be it fashion or furniture, architecture or art, let’s not forget that it must be nurtured and supported too. London’s sparkly creative reputation isn’t a fluke but is in large part derived from its historically excellent art school system. The system has produced individuals as diverse as vacuum cleaner king James Dyson and the maker of this year’s Amy Whitehouse documentary, Asif Kapadia. Directors of Porsche and Mercedes design studios, the head of special effects at George Lucas’s Industrial Light and Magic, top designers at Chloé, Armani, Chanel and Louis Vuitton – they’ve all come out of UK art schools, as have countless significant creative “movements”. Schools are not solely bricks and mortar, but the students and teachers inside them. And exceptional types of both lead to exceptional results. When I met the American artist Robert Irwin recently, who tutored students including Ed Ruscha and Chris Burden in California in the 1960s and 70s, he said: “The good ones don’t want any teaching. I just massaged their brains.” From 1973 to 1988, that’s what the artist and writer Michael Craig-Martin did at Goldsmiths college in London, and his adventurous methods of teaching fine art helped to produce Damien Hirst, Sarah Lucas, Gary Hume and others labelled with the Young British Artist tag. Sheep floating in tanks, paintings rendered in Dulux gloss – the tabloids might have had a field day, but the world woke up to London as a key art destination. Over at St Martin’s college, between 1992 and 2014, the frequently terrifying Louise Wilson guided fashion designers such as Alexander McQueen and Christopher Kane into towering talents – as well as producers of valuable exports. The posthumous McQueen exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum in New York attracted 670,000 visitors; and a further half a million when it came to London. But straitened financial times in education are threatening to take away from our art schools exactly what makes them so special and so effective. Practitioner teachers, for a start, whose specialist knowledge is key to good art education: expertise is hard won and remains the bedrock of innovation. In parts of the Royal College of Art, the crucible of London postgraduate design education, practitioners are being replaced by “educationalists” and academics, and its courses are in danger of becoming a commodity to be sold to those who can afford to pay. The free-wheeling creative journeys that brought on designers such as Thomas Heatherwick are being replaced by more prescribed experiences. Fabio Piras, Louise Wilson’s successor at Central St Martin’s, said recently that a student needs at least £25,000 a year to get through the college’s fashion MA. London art schools were once the ultimate social leveller, where an alumnus of Eton had no special advantage over a council estate kid. But it seems less likely that the artist Chris Ofili, who grew up modestly in Manchester, would be able to take up a place at the Royal College now (he studied there in the early 1990s). His large-scale glittery paintings now sell for millions. In economic terms alone, the relatively small investment in his education has reaped a rather handsome return. But where once the art school was a meeting place of all classes – which created a particular energy and range of ideas and experience – it’s now a global meeting place, absorbing students from far and wide and offering a cross-pollination of cultures instead. That’s wonderful too in other ways, but possibly a temporary situation. Countries such as China will not be educational cash-cows forever. In a fierce drive to move from “made in China” to “designed in China”, the country is setting up its own schools, sometimes with staff who’ve thrown in the towel in London. The art and design world being what it is – rebellious, ingenious, innovative and bloody-minded – is taking matters into its own hands. An alternative art college is being set up by the conceptual artist Ryan Gander in Suffolk; and an independent space run from a former library in Hackney – Open˚ School East – is supported by practising artists and the occasional Tate curator who give their time for free. The London School of Architecture, chaired by the architect Nigel Coates, allows students to work nearly full-time, and have their employers pay their fees. And a group of designers in south London is looking for a space in which to carry out their educational dreams. London fashion week will return in February, when it will be sharing the city with the Baftas and the Brits, which reward film and music respectively. You might find Steve McQueen, the Oscar-winning filmmaker, at the first, and the musician Jarvis Cocker at the second, both fine art graduates from London schools. Just look where it can all lead.
